III. METHODOLOGY
06/28/2021 Special Investigation Intake 2021C0214022
06/30/2021 Special Investigation Initiated - Face to Face interviews with
Administrator 1, Youth A, Supervisor 1, Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3,
and Staff 4.
06/30/2021 Inspection Completed On-site
07/07/2021 Inspection Completed-BCAL Sub. Compliance
ALLEGATION:
On Saturday 06/26/2021, Youth A had to be restrained after fighting with another
child at Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home. Supervisor 1 had his hands on the front
and back of his neck for just one second, during the restraint. Afterwards, Youth A
was checked out by another Supervisor. Youth A had photos taken and he had no
injuries. Youth A was offered ice and ibuprofen. A Nurse will be checking out Youth
A on 06/28/2021. This was incident was captured on video.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed Administrator 1 in person at the facility on 6/30/21. He reported
being made aware of the allegations by Supervisor 1 shortly after Supervisor 1
reviewed the video recording of the incident on the same day as the incident. He
also reported observing the video recording and concluding Supervisor 1 did not use
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037
 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

the appropriate behavior management techniques. He reported speaking will the five
other staff involved about the incident, and he also reported Supervisor 1 has not
worked at the facility since the incident.
I interviewed Youth A in person at the facility on 6/30/21. He reported being told
by Supervisor 1 to go to his room and while he attempted to go to his room
“Supervisor 1 grabbed me by my neck”. He also reported being choked by
Supervisor 1 because “he squeezed a little bit”. He had no further information to
provide and ended when he reported feeling safe at the facility and never being
abused by staff.
I interviewed Staff 1 in person at the facility on 6/30/21. She reported being
present during the allegations and stated, “I witnessed Supervisor 1 grabbing
Youth’s neck and forcing him into his room”. She reported staff “had the situation
under control and Youth A was going to his room at the time of Supervisor 1’s
intervention. She also reported not believing Youth A was any type of threat to the
staff present or any other youth. She ended the interview when she reported telling
Supervisor 1, he had “choked Youth A”.
I interviewed Staff 2 in person at the facility on 6/30/21. He also reported being
present during the allegations and he stated, “when I got into the room, Youth A was
acting out and refusing to go to his room”. He also reported Youth A was attempting
to get to the other room to continue the fight with another youth that began the
incident. He stated, “we were trying to calm Youth A down and he was no longer a
threat to us and not combative towards us”. Staff 2 continued, “Youth A stepped up
on a chair and at that point if felt like he needed to be restrained so I began the
process. I put my arms around him and held him while beginning to walk towards his
room.” He reported Supervisor 1 “came out of nowhere and placed his hands near
Youth A’s neck but his hands were near the neck area only a couple of seconds”. He
reported Supervisor 1 did not use the trained method of behavior management.
I interviewed Staff 3 in person at the facility on 6/30/21. He also reported being
present during the allegations and stated, “Youth A was not complying, but he was
also not putting up much of a struggle. We were inching him closer to his room.” He
reported Supervisor 1 came into the situation and “told Youth A to go to his room but
Youth A didn’t go to his room”. He also reported Supervisor 1 “reached over to grab
Youth A and touched him in his neck area.” He reported Supervisor 1 never choked
Youth A and “some staff may have thought Youth A was choked but Supervisor 1
only touched him on the neck”. He also reported the same as other staff that
Supervisor 1 did not use an approved intervention technique with Youth A.
I interviewed Staff 4 in person at the facility on 6/30/21. As with other staff
interviewed, Staff 4 reported being present during the allegations. He gave a similar
description of the incident between Supervisor 1 and Youth A and reported
Supervisor 1 had his hands on Youth A’s neck for “a few seconds”. He also reported
if Supervisor 1 were choking Youth A he would not have been able to say, “get your

 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

fucking hands off my neck”. He also reported Supervisor 1 was not using an
approved technique during his intervention.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 in person at the facility on 6/30/21. He reported
receiving a “level one call around 10 o’clock in the morning” of the incident. He also
reported Staff 1 called this report in and “sounded distressed” so he “got there
quickly”. He reported getting to the location of the situation and finding Youth A
fighting with another youth. He also reported helping with the other youth and having
the other staff escort Youth A to the other “pod”. He provided the following, “I looked
up and saw Youth A beginning to move to his room but then stopped and took his
sweater off. This is a sign a youth is getting ready to fight and then he pushed away
from Staff 4 before breaking away from Staff 1 when she attempted to grab him
around the waist.” He reported having a belief the staff engaged with Youth A were
in danger because of his history and size. He also reported leaving the other youth
with another staff so he could help with Youth A in the other “pod”. He reported
going into the other “pod” and the staff were silent and did not provide any
information on the situation to him. He reported normally, the staff would tell him
what was occurring. He reported observing Youth A step up on a chair and
attempting to break away from Staff 2 before he intervened and “tried to support
Staff 2 so he didn’t get hit or hurt”. He also reported Youth A was “hovering over me
and I believed he would hit Staff 2 or myself, so my first thought was to push Youth
A into Staff 2’s arms”. Supervisor 1 reported a belief this would allow Staff 2 to get a
better hold on Youth A, so he “reached up but I reached up to high”. He reported he
was attempting to turn Youth A and when he “realized where my hands where I
dropped my hands and let Staff 2 take full control”. He also reported pushing Youth
A into his room in his effort to get Youth A into his room and “away from staff”.
Supervisor 1 ended the interview when he reported not using the correct techniques
during the incident.
On 7/1/21 a phone message was left with Youth A’s probation officer but at the time
of this report being written, no response has been received.
Documents Reviewed:
I reviewed the Human Resources file for Supervisor 1. Documentation within the file
indicates he has been employed at the facility for the past twenty-one years. Of this
time, he has been in the supervisor role for the past thirteen years. There is only one
documented disciplinary action taken with Supervisor 1 and this occurred on May 6,
2009. He was cited for dispensing the wrong prescription medication to a youth at
the facility. The letter indicated if any further errors occurred then disciplinary action
would be taken. Training records indicated Supervisor 1 is up to date on all his
required training, and he is a trainer for the behavior management techniques used
at the facility.
I reviewed the manual for “Nonviolent Crisis Intervention” (CPI) used by the facility.
There were no physical interventions that would involve a staff touching or coming
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037
 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

close to touching a youth in the neck area or pushing a youth.
I reviewed the facility’s Policy and Procedure for “non-violent Restraint”, Policy 5:10.
This policy states, “staff should only use the minimum amount of force necessary”
and “should assess the situation”.
I reviewed the video recording of the incident. The recording begins at 10:59:14.017
-10:59:56.510 AM 06/26/2021 with a view of the “pod” in which the incident took
place. Staff and Youth A are observed entering the area. There are four staff present
and Youth A walks away from the staff and removes his sweatshirt. Youth A is
observed to be trying to get back to the door they entered the area from, and staff
are surrounding him and attempting to block his path. One staff is escorting Youth A
away from the door and towards his room. Another staff is walking ahead and
appears to be opening the bedroom door. The other staff are standing between
Youth A and the door leading to the other area. Youth A appears to be struggling to
get away from the staff who are holding him by his arms. Other staff are standing
just outside of arms reach surrounding Youth A. Supervisor 1 is observed walking
into the area. The other staff have a hold of Youth A and are surrounding him. Staff
2 escorts Youth A towards his room when Youth A steps upon a chair. Supervisor 1
is standing in front of Youth A with Staff 2 holding him from behind. Other staff are
standing close by and surround them. Staff 2 begins to move Youth A off the chair
and towards his room. Supervisor 1 moves forward and grabs Youth A near the neck
area. His left hand appears to be on the neck area while his right hand is on Youth
A’s left shoulder. Staff 2, Youth A, and Supervisor 1 move just out of camera view
but just prior, Supervisor 1 can be observed moving his hands from near the neck
area of Youth A.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.10177 Resident restraint.
(1) The facility shall establish and follow written policy and
procedures specifying the use of resident restraint.
ANALYSIS: Evidence provided through interviews, written documentation
and video review do support the allegations of Supervisor 1 not
following the written policies and procedures during the restraint
of Youth A. Although, the allegation of Supervisor 1 choking
Youth A is not supported as evidenced by most witnesses and
the video recording. It is clear Supervisor 1 failed to follow the
approved CPI techniques sanctioned by the facility.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
